title: Data Sources
text:
Data Sources
The framework uses diverse data streams to capture food safety risks:

Inspection Records: Boston Food Establishment Database (2006â€“Present).
Environmental Data: Weather, power outages, and urban heat island effects.
Citizen Reports: Boston 311 logs on sanitation and pest complaints.
Business Characteristics: Details like operating hours and price range.
Socioeconomic Data: To assess vulnerabilities and disparities.

title: About
text:
About This Project
This project focuses on creating an AI framework for restaurant food safety in Boston, Massachusetts. It aims to predict food safety violations and prevent foodborne illness through advanced AI techniques and integrated data streams.

title: Objectives
text:
Develop AI-powered tools to predict food safety violations.
Integrate multiple data streams (e.g., inspections, environmental data).
Prevent foodborne illness through proactive interventions.

title: Discussion
text:
The framework represents a paradigm shift in food safety management, moving from reactive to proactive strategies.
Insights help policymakers allocate resources effectively and equitably.





Expand to other cities and jurisdictions.
Explore additional data sources for improved predictions.

title: Andrew Ruiz Dissertation Project
text:
This project explores integrated risk insights for restaurant food safety in Boston, Massachusetts.



Predict food safety violations using AI models.
Integrate environmental and operational data streams.
Proactively reduce foodborne illness risks.





Cascading failure modeling with PyTorch.
Geospatial clustering for violation patterns.
Explainable AI for transparent insights.

text:
Cascading failure modeling with PyTorch.
Geospatial clustering for violation patterns.
Explainable AI for transparent insights.

title: Methods
text:
Cascading Failure Modeling: Simulates interconnected risks, such as heatwaves impacting refrigeration.
Geospatial Clustering: Identifies hotspots for violations.
Explainable AI (XAI): Ensures transparency in risk prediction.





Modeled heat-related illness and death.
Evaluated the cost-effectiveness of interventions like cooling centers.
